descriptions:
Here is a 276-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Cultural Evolution of Kinship Diversity: Variation in Language, Cognition, and Social Norms Regarding Family

This interdisciplinary project investigates the evolution of kinship diversity across cultures and over time, examining the complex interplay between language, cognition, and social norms. The proposed research integrates macro- and micro-evolutionary approaches to understand how kinship terminologies and family norms change, and how these changes are reflected in language usage and children's acquisition of kinship concepts.

The project consists of three components: VARIKIN-Evolution, which applies comparative phylogenetic modeling to analyze kinship terminologies across eight language families; VARIKIN-Usage, which employs corpus linguistics, surveys, and interviews to study the usage of kinship language in spoken and written forms; and VARIKIN-Development, which uses participant observation and elicitation tasks to investigate children's acquisition and understanding of kinship in small-scale, non-Western communities.

The objectives of this project are to analyze patterns of kinship change, examine the impact of social norms on kinship terminology, link individual usage patterns to historical processes, and characterize the cross-cultural acquisition of kinship by children. By integrating insights from linguistics, anthropology, psychology, and cognitive science, this project aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the cultural evolution of kinship diversity, shedding light on the universal and variable aspects of human kinship systems. The proposed research has significant implications for our understanding of human sociality, language, and culture, and will contribute to the development of a more nuanced theory of cultural evolution.
